importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when President Donald Trump made his statement threatening to 'go in and kill' Hamas if it continues killing in Gaza, marking a significant escalation in his rhetoric following a recent ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period just before Trump’s new threats, when he initially downplayed Hamas attacks and declared the war 'over' after the ceasefire deal was signed.
The period during which Trump escalated his rhetoric, warning of potential military action and stating that Israel would resume fighting if Hamas fails to honor the truce.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump threatened to 'go in and kill' Hamas if the group continues killing civilians in Gaza, signaling a sharp shift from his earlier optimistic stance after a ceasefire deal.
Trump clarified that U.S. military forces would not be directly involved, but that 'people very close, very nearby' would carry out action under U.S. auspices.
Hamas has been accused of reasserting control in Gaza by targeting Palestinians accused of collaborating with Israeli forces, raising concerns about the stability of the ceasefire.
Trump expressed confidence that Hamas would honor the agreement, but warned that if they fail, the U.S. would intervene to ensure compliance.
Trump previously dismissed reports of Hamas executions, stating that eliminating gangs was acceptable, but has now changed tone to a more aggressive stance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has escalated his rhetoric by threatening to allow Israel to resume military operations against Hamas in Gaza if the group continues killing civilians, marking a sharp reversal from his earlier claims that the war was effectively over. Despite clarifying that U.S. forces would not be directly involved, Trump emphasized that nearby actors would carry out action under U.S. authority. This comes amid reports that Hamas has used the ceasefire to reassert control in Gaza, targeting Palestinians accused of collaborating with Israel. Trump previously dismissed such actions as minor, but now insists Hamas must disarm or face consequences, and he expressed confidence that the ceasefire will hold, though he remains prepared to act if it is violated.
title: Trump threatens to 'go in and kill' Hamas if group doesn’t stop killing in Gaza
